children.name: succeed
children.definition: /səkˈsiːd/  to do something that you hoped to do, tried to do, or wanted to do: thành công
examples: ▪ She wanted to be the first woman to climb Mount Everest and she almost succeeded.
▪ I tried to reassure Billy’s mother that it was a passing phase, but I don’t think I succeeded.
▪ Muir succeeds where other designers have failed -- her clothes are original, yet stylish.

children.name: succeed in doing something
examples: ▪ In one year, we’ve succeeded in increasing profits by 40%.

children.name: succeed at
examples: ▪ I admired Goldie, because she had succeeded at a task that had even defeated my mother.

children.name: manage
children.definition: to succeed in doing something difficult after trying very hard, especially when you almost do not succeed.Manage to do somethingis very commonly used instead ofsucceed in doing somethingin everyday English : xoay xở được
examples: ▪ Martin still hasn’t got his invalidity pension sorted out, but he’s managing all right at the moment.
▪ If you hadn’t have been here, I don’t think I would have managed.
▪ I don’t know how he managed it, but the crisis is over.
▪ Can you manage that door Mike? It looks awfully heavy.

children.name: manage to dosth
examples: ▪ He finally managed to find an apartment near his office.
▪ At least three hostages managed to escape.

children.name: manage with/without sth
examples: ▪ Well, I suppose we could just about manage without electricity for the night.

children.name: be successful
children.definition: /biː səkˈsesfəl/  to succeed in doing something, especially something that needs a lot of work or effort such as passing a test or getting a job:thành công
examples: ▪ Does Joey have a realistic chance of being successful at the audition?
successfully[adverb] B2
▪ Mr Malik has successfully completed the advanced course in Business Management.

children.name: be successful in doing something
examples: ▪ If I’m successful in raising over £500, those funds will go to the Bible School.

children.name: have some success
children.definition: / have limited success to be fairly successful in doing sth, or to achieve part of what you wanted to achieve:thành công nhất định
examples: Our aim was to disrupt the enemy’s transport network and we had some success.
If we only have some success in reducing the number infected with HIV, I feel it will have been worthwhile.

children.name: have some success/have limited success in doing sth
examples: The Santa Barbara seismic research team has had some success in predicting earthquakes.

children.name: make progress
children.definition: to gradually start to achieve something that you want to achieve, by working hard:có tiến bộ
examples: ▪ I’m not very good at Japanese yet, but I feel I am making progress.
▪ We have made very great progress in reducing the number of deaths on our roads.

children.name: make progress with/towards/on
examples: ▪ At last I began to make some progress with my research.

children.name: make progress in doing sth
examples: ▪ BEA has made good progress in implementing the new health and safety regulations.

children.name: achieve
children.definition: to succeed in doing sth important, especially sth that other people will admire you for: đạt được
examples: She’s achieved a lot in the short time she’s been with the company.
The reason I achieve good results is because I work hard -- and so could you.
When you get your MA, you really feel that you’ve achieved something.
He had achieved all his goals for the organization, and felt there were no challenges left there for him.
Frances achieved very good exam results.
Wilson has achieved considerable success as an artist.
She eventually achieved her goal of becoming a professor.
If we are toachieveourgoals, we have to plan properly.
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually say someonegetsa result rather thanachievesit:
Hegotgood grades in his final exams.

children.name: accomplish
children.definition: formalto succeed in doing or finishing sth good that you have planned to do, after trying hard for a long time: hoàn thành
examples: What exactly do you hope to accomplish this year?
She found the job frustrating, and felt she wasn’t accomplishing anything there.
We have accomplished all we set out to do.
Mission accomplished(= we have done what we intended to do ).
The governmentaccomplisheditsobjectiveof reducing violent crime.
What do you hope to accomplish this year?

children.name: get results
children.definition: if you get results, you achieve what you are trying to do: gặt hái kết quả
examples: It was three or four years before we really started getting results.
This shows that if we devote sufficient energy and resources to a problem, we get results.
As I manager, I pride myself on getting results.

children.name: attain
children.definition: formal to reach or succeed in getting something; to achieve : dành được
examples: He has attained the highest grade in his music exams.
We need to identify the best ways of attaining ourobjectives/goals.
India attained independence in 1947, after decades of struggle.

children.name: to succeed in doing sth difficult
make it
children.definition: especially spoken to succeed in doing something that is difficult or that seems impossible:thành công, làm được
examples: ▪ Gina has her driving test today. I hope she makes it.
▪ He went out for it, he played hard, and he made it.
▪ Jody thinks only three teams will make it to the final.
▪ Did Margaret make it home the other night?
▪ Will he make it out alive?

children.name: get there
children.definition: especially spoken to succeed in doing sth, especially after a lot of effort over a long period of time:thành công hoàn thành việc gì, tới đích
examples: I aim to have my own company by the time I’m thirty, but sometimes I wonder if I’ll ever get there.
Anna found the coursework hard, but knew she’d get there in the end.
I knew we’d get there eventually, it was just a question of when.

children.name: do it U
children.definition: do it especially spoken to succeed in doing sth, especially sth difficult or sth that needs a lot of effort:làm được, thành công
examples: We did it! We won the cup!
You did it! Congratulations!

children.name: pull off
children.definition: /bring off/carry off informal to manage to do sth difficult, when other people did not think that you could succeed:
examples: In the opening game, Italy pulled off a sensational 1-0 victory over Germany.
I think you need a really good sense of humour to carry off something like this.
We had a hard time bringing off the last conference we held here.
I’d hardly cooked a proper meal for years, and I was wondering if I could still pull it off.
I doubt if we could have carried it off without your help.
Italy pulled off a great victory over Germany.
I’d never performed on my own before, and wasn’t sure if I could pull it off.

children.name: turn up trumps
children.definition: turn/come up trumps informal if sb comes or turns up trumps, they succeed in doing something difficult or providing something that is needed, especially when this makes you feel pleased or grateful:
examples: We were getting into serious difficulties, but Ron came up trumps again.
Well, I got three people interested in helping, so if they all turn up trumps, we should reach our target.

children.name: when sth happens without any problems at all
go like clockwork
children.definition: if sth you have arranged such as an event or journey goes like clockwork, it happens in exactly the way that was planned, with no problems at all: đều đặn như đồng hồ
examples: After all that fuss, everything went like clockwork. You should have seen it.

children.name: ‘Everything go all right?’ ‘Like clockwork.’
examples: All through that summer, work on the farm went like clockwork.

children.name: go smoothly
children.definition: if a plannedevent, journey, piece of work etc goes smoothly, there are no problems to spoil it: diễn ra trơn tru
examples: If all goes smoothly, elections are expected in May.

children.name: In rehearsal, everything went smoothly, even the difficult fight scenes
examples: My presentation went remarkably smoothly, until one student asked an awkward question right at the end.

children.name: without a hitch
children.definition: if a planned action or event happens without a hitch, it happens exactly as planned with no problems at all, even though some may have been expected: thuận buồm xuôi gió, trôi chảy

children.name: The first phase of the operation was completed without a hitch
examples: TCI say they hope that approval will be granted for the takeover without a hitch.
Except for the priest forgetting the groom’s middle name, the ceremony came off without a hitch.

children.name: when sth has the result that you want it to have
succeed
children.definition: if something that you plan to do or try to do succeeds, you get the result that you hoped for: thành công
examples: ▪ Both sides could make these talks succeed by seeking a real and lasting peace.
▪ As long as the financial crisis continues, economic reform cannot possibly succeed
succeed in doing sth
▪ None of the measures taken by the government have succeeded in reducing the spread of violent crime.

children.name: successful
children.definition: if sth that you plan to do or try to do is successful you get the result that you hoped for: thành công
examples: ▪ If the treatment is successful, she could be back at school next month.
▪ a small but successful program to boost the number of African-Americans getting into college
highly successfulvery successful
▪ It was ahighly successful campaign.
the most successful
▪ This has been Baltimore’s most successful art show ever.
so successful (. . . that)
▪ The case of Thailand illustrates why family planning programs have been so successful in many countries.
prove successfulbe successful
▪ The scheme was started in January 2000, and has proved largely successful.
successfully[adv] B2
▪ The film successfully combines a good story line with a serious political message.

children.name: work
children.definition: /wɜːʳk/  if a plan or methodworks, it produces the result that you want:có kết quả tốt

children.name: ▪ ‘I can’t open this jar.’ ‘Try putting it under hot water. That sometimes works.’
examples: ▪ I think your treatment worked Arnie, my headache’s gone.
▪ The recipe works just as well if you cook the fish in a microwave.

children.name: go well U
children.definition: go well/ˌgəʊ ˈwel/  if something goes well, such as a meeting, party, or performance, everything happens in the way you wanted and there are no problems
examples: ▪ Ray met my parents for the first time this weekend, and it went really well.
▪ The audition was OK, but it could have gone better I suppose.
▪ Most people seem to think the party went well
go well for
▪ Good luck with the project, and I hope everything goes well for you.

children.name: have some success
children.definition: /hæv ˌsʌm səkˈses/  if a plan, method etc has some success, it is fairly successful: khá thành công
examples: ▪ The early warning system has had some success; for example Pacific coast residents get four hours notice of a potential earthquake.
▪ Only in the late 1990s did efforts to reduce sectarian violence have some success.

children.name: turn out right
children.definition: come out right//ˌkʌm aʊt ˈraɪt, ˌtɜːʳn aʊt ˈraɪt/  if somethingcomes out rightor turns out right, it succeeds in the end when it had seemed as though it would fail:thành công vào phút cuối
examples: ▪ People enjoy romantic fiction because it offers a reassurance that things will always come out right.
▪ Just when it looks as though everything will turn out right, tragedy strikes and Jenny dies of a fatal illness.

children.name: come out right in the end: cuối cùng cũng thành công
examples: ▪ She’s scared she’ll fail her exams, but I think everything’ll come out right in the end.

children.name: come off
children.definition: if sth that you arrange such as a party or trip comes off, it happens successfully even though there are problems in arranging it:
examples: ▪ We had hoped to organize a trip to the theatre tonight, but it didn’t come off.
▪ Good try Tim. Shame it didn’t quite come off.

children.name: pay off
children.definition: /ˌpeɪ ˈɒf/  if hard work, effort, a risk etcpays off, it has a successful result at a later time:có kết quả tốt sau này

children.name: ▪ I think if you show a bit more consideration for other road users, you’ll find it pays off
examples: ▪ We put a lot of hard work into local initiatives, and that’s really starting to pay off now.

children.name: bear fruit
children.definition: if a plan, idea, or actionbears fruit, it has the successful result that it was intended to have, especially after a long period of time: gặt được hoa trái
examples: The campaign for debt relief will not bear fruit for another two or three years.
I hope you feel your involvement has been worthwhile and has borne fruit.

children.name: fruitful
children.definition: a meeting, discussion etc that isfruitful is successful, useful, and produces good results: nhiều hoa trái
examples: ▪ So far, the investigation has not been very fruitful.
▪ This was one of the most fruitful debates of the conference.
▪ If the talks prove fruitful, the working groups will start bargaining in May.

children.name: deliver
children.definition: verbPRODUCE

children.name: fulfil
children.definition: -ll-,US usuallyfulfillverbMAKE HAPPEN

children.name: 1. to do something that is expected, hoped for or promised or to cause it to happen
examples: A school fails if it does not fulfil theneeds/requirementsof its pupils. At the age of 45, she finally fulfilled herambitionto run a marathon. Zoos fulfil an importantfunctionin the protection of rare species. He has failed to fulfil hisdutiesas a father.

We're looking for a very specific sort of person and this woman seems to fulfil all of ourcriteria. So did the course fulfil all yourexpectations? We're suing our suppliers for failing to fulfil their contract.

children.name: hit
children.definition: verbhitting,hit,hitREACH

children.name: meet
children.definition: verbmet,metSATISFY

children.name: establish yourself
children.definition: establishyourselfformal

children.name: to be in a successful position over a long period of time
examples: He has established himself as the leading candidate in the election.

children.name: go from strength to strength
children.definition: mainly UK

children.name: to gradually become more successful
examples: The firm's gone from strength to strength since the new factory was built.

children.name: excel yourself
children.definition: excelyourself

children.name: to do something better than you usually do
examples: The British team have excelled themselves this year to reach the finals.

children.name: shine
children.definition: verbshoneorshined,shoneorshinedABILITY

children.name: catch on
children.definition: phrasal verbBECOME POPULAR

children.name: 1. to become fashionable or popular
examples: I wonder if the game will ever catch on with young people?

children.name: count towards
children.definition: sthphrasal verb

children.name: to be part of what is needed to complete or achieve something
examples: The work that the students do during the year will count towards their final degrees.

children.name: stand out
children.definition: phrasal verb

children.name: 2. to be much better than other similar things or people
examples: We had lots of good applicants for the job, but one stood outfromthe rest.
